question.text: How many grams of a sucrose (mol wt. = 342) should be dissolved in 100 g water in order to produce a solution with a 105.0℃ difference between the freezing point and boiling temperature? (kf=1.86 C/m, kb=0.151℃)

Boiling point (Tb) = 100 + ΔTb = 100 + kbm

Freezing point (Tf) = 0 − ΔTf =  − kfmTb − Tf = (100+kbm) − (−kfm)

105 = 100 + 0.51m + 1.86m

$2.37\ m = 5\ or\ \ m = \frac{5}{2.37} = 2.11$

∴ Weight of sucrose to be dissolved in 100 g water

$= \frac{2.11 \times 342}{1000} \times 100 = 72g$ .

question.text: Equimolar solution in the same solvent have

d.text: Different boiling and different freezing points
Same boiling and same freezing points
Same freezing point but different boiling point
Same boiling point but different freezing point

solution.text:
Boiling point and freezing point depend on kb (molal elevation constant) and kf (molal depression constant) of the solvent. Thus, equimolar solution (of the non-electrolyte) will have same boiling point and also same freezing point.

ΔTf = kf × molality

ΔTb = kb × molality

Note In this question nature of solute has not been mentioned. Hence, we have assumed that solute is non-electrolyte.

question.text:
During osmosis, flow of water through a semipermeable
membrane is

d.text: from solution having lower concentration only
from solution having higher concentration only
from both sides of semipermeable membrane with equal flow rates

from both sides of semipermeable membrane with unequal flow
rates.

solution.text:
Osmosis is the phenomenon of flow of pure solvent from
the solvent to the solution or from a less concentrated solution to a
more concentrated solution through a semipermeable membrane. Common
semipermeable membranes are permeable to certain solute particles also.
Intact, there is no perfect semipermeable membrane. Therefore we can say
that flow of water through a semipermeable membrane takes place both
sides with unequal rates.

question.text: At 25∘C, the total pressure of an ideal solution obtained by mixing 3 moles of ‘A’ and 2 moles of ‘B’, is 184 torr. What is the vapour pressure (in torr) of pure ‘B’ at the same temperature? (Vapour pressure of pure ‘A’ at 25∘C is 200 torr)

solution.text:
$P = p_{A}^{\circ}\ \left( \frac{n_{A}}{n_{A} + n_{B}} \right) + p_{B}^{\circ}\left( \frac{n_{B}}{n_{A} + n_{B}} \right)\ $

$184 = 200\left( \frac{3}{3 + 2} \right)p_{B}^{\circ}\left( \frac{2}{3 + 2} \right)\ \ \ $

$184 = 200 \times \frac{3}{5} + p_{B}^{\circ} \times \frac{2}{5}$

184 = 200+$p_{B}^{\circ}\frac{2}{5}$

64 = $p_{B}^{\circ}\frac{2}{5}$

pB∘ = $\frac{64 \times 5}{2}$ =160 torr

question.text:
The vapour pressure of a solvent decreased by 10 mm of
mercury when a non-volatile solute was added to the solvent. The mole
fraction of the solute in the solution is 0.2. What should be the mole
fraction of the solvent if the decrease in the vapour pressure is to be
20 mm of mercury?

solution.text:
x1 (mole fraction of solute) = 0.2

From Raoult’s law

$\frac{P^{0} - P_{s}}{P^{0}} = x_{1}\ \ \Rightarrow \ \frac{10}{P^{0}\ }$ ⇒  0.2 ⇒ P0 = 50 mm

Again, when P0 – Ps = 20 mm, then

$\frac{P^{0} - P_{s}}{P^{0}}$ = mole fraction of solute = $\frac{20}{50}$ = 0.4

⇒ mole fraction of solvent = 1 – 0.4 = 0.6

M=Molecular weight solute=?

$$\frac{P^{0} - p}{p^{o}} = \frac{w \times M}{W \times m}\ or\ \frac{200 - 195}{200} = \frac{2 \times 78}{78 \times m}$$

$or\ \frac{5}{200} = \frac{2}{m}\ \ \therefore m = 80$.

Hence, molality.

question.text:
Concentrated aqueous sulphuric acid is 98%
H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> by mass and has a density of 1.80 g
mL<sup>-I</sup>. Volume of acid required to make one litre of 0.1 M

solution.text:

Weight of H2SO4 = 98 g

Weight of solution = 100 g

∴ Volume of solution = $\frac{mass}{density} = \frac{100}{1.80}mL$

= 55.55 mL = 0.0555 L

Molarity of solution = $\frac{98}{93\ \times 0.0555}M = 18.02M$

Let V mL of this H2SO4 are used to prepare 1 litre of 0.1M H2SO4

or V × 18.02 = 1000 × 0.1 ⇒ V = $\frac{1000\ \times 0.1}{18.02} = 5.55\ mL$

question.text:
Henry’s constant (in kbar) for four gases α, β, γ and δ in water at 298 K is given below.

(density of water = 103 kg m–3 at 298 K) The table implies that:

d.text: α has the highest solubility in water at a given pressure
solubility of γ at 308 K is lower than at 298 K.
The pressure of a 55.5 molal solution of γ is 1 bar.
The pressure of a 55.5 molal solution of δ is 250 bar.

solution.text:
(a) From Henry’s law p = KH(x)

Higher the value of KH smaller will be the solubility of the gas, so γ is more soluble.

(b) Through solubility of the gases will decreases with increase in temperature but this conclusion cannot be drawn from the given table.

(c) For γ pγ = (KH)γ. (x)γ

= $2 \times 10^{- 5}\left\lbrack \frac{55.5}{55.5 + \ \frac{1000}{18}} \right\rbrack{= 10}^{- 5}$ k bar = 10−2 bar.

(d) For δ

pδ= (KH)δ. (x)δ = 0.5$\left\lbrack \frac{55.5}{55.5 + \ \frac{1000}{18}} \right\rbrack$

= 0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25 k bar = 250 bar.

question.text: A 0.1 molal aqueous solution of a weak acid is 30% ionized. If Kf for water is 1.86°C/m, the freezing point of the solution will be

solution.text:
We know that ∆Tf = i × Kf × m

Here i is van't Hoff's factor.

i for weak acid is 1 + ∝.

Here ∝ is degree of dissociation i.e., 30/100 = 0.3

∴ i = 1 + ∝ = 1 + 0.3 = 1.3

∆Tf = i × Kf × m = 1.3 × 1.86 k 0.1 = 0.24

Freezing point = − 0.24.

increase. Hence, higher the degree of ionization greater would be the

question.text: The efficiency of a fuel cell is given by

solution.text:
The thermal efficiency,  η of a fuel conversion device is the amount of useful energy produced relative to the change in enthalpy, ∆H between the product land feed streams.

$$\eta\ = \ \frac{useful\ energy\ }{\mathrm{\Delta}H}$$

In an ideal case of an electrochemical convertor, such as a fuel cell, the change in Gibb's free energy, ∆G of the reaction is available as useful electric energy at that temperature of the conversion.

Hence $\eta_{ideal}\ = \ \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}G\ }{\mathrm{\Delta}H}$

question.text: The best way to prevent rusting of iron is

solution.text:
During rusting, oxidation of iron takes place, i.e. , it acts as anode. Hence, coating/connecting iron with metal of lower reduction potential (in comparison to iron) is the best way to prevent its rusting. In this process, the metal with low reduction potential undergoes oxidation (i.e. acts as anode) while iron acts as cathode. (Cathodic protection)

Use of saline water accelerates the process of rusting thereby increasing the electric conduction of electrolyte solution formed on the metal surface.

question.text: Standard free energies of formation (in kJ/mol) at 298K and –237.2, –394.4 and –8.2 for H2O(7), CO2(g) and pentane(g) respectively. The value of for the pentane-oxygen fuel cell is

solution.text:
C5H12(g) + 8O2(g) → 5CO2(g) + 6H2O(I)

∆G0 = [(–394.4 × 5) + (–237.2 × 5)] – [(–8.2) + (8 × 0)]

= –3387.5 kJ

Note that the standard free energy change of elementary substances is taken as zero.

For the fuel cell, the complete cell reaction is :

C5H12(g)+ 8O2(g) → 5CO2(g) + 6H2O(I)

Which is the combination of the following two half reactions:

C5H12(g)+ 10H2O(I) → 5CO2(g) + 32H+ + 32e and

8O2(g) + 32H+ + 32e → 16H2O(I)

Therefore, the number of electrons exchanged is 32 here, means n = 32. This is the trickiest part of the problem.

∆G0 = –nFE0 = –3387.5 × 103 J

= –32 × 96500 J/Volt × E0

Thus E0 = 1.09698 V

question.text: The oxidation potential values of A, B, C and D are -0.03, +0.108 V,-0.07 V and +0.1 V respectively. The non-spontaneous cell reaction taking place between anode and cathode

solution.text:
(i) The electrode with higher oxidation potential acts as anode and electrode with lower oxidation potential acts as cathode.

(ii) Cell reaction is spontaneous when Ecell is positive. In case of A and B ; oxidation potential of A  =  − 0.03 oxidation potential of B =  + 0.108

Because oxidation potential of B is more than A so oxidation of A is not possible. The cell having A as anode and B as cathode is not possible.

Therefore, non-spontaneous cell reaction takes place between A and B.

question.text:
Dipping iron article into a strongly alkaline solution
of sodium phosphate

solution.text:
In electrochemical series, iron is placed below sodium, so it cannot displace sodium from its salt solution. Hence, no reaction takes place.

Fe + Na3PO4 → No reaction.

question.text:
Based on the following information, arrange four metals A, B, C and D in order of decreasing ability to act as reducing agent

  1. A, B & C react with 1 M HCl to give H2

  2. When C is added to solutions of the other metal ions, metal B and D are found

  3. Metal C does not reduce An+

solution.text:
(1) A > C > B > D

(2) Based on "whenC is added to the solution of other metal ions then mettalicB and D are formed" this statement, C can be oxidized by B and D as there is formation of B and D.And as we know,any element can be oxidized by the ions listed below it in the series.

(3) Therefore C must be more reactive than Band D as it can displace both of them but less reactive than A because A is not formed which makes A most reactive.

(4) And based upon "only a,b,c react with with 1mole HClto give H2​" this condition,metals A,B,C are all above hydrogen and D is below it because D cannot form hydrogen. Therefore D is the least reactive metal. That is greater the reactivity of the element, greater would be its power to act as a reducing agent.

Velocity of NO3− is greater than that of K+
Velocity of both K+ and NO3−are nearly the same

solution.text: The salt is used to make ‘salt-bridge’ must be such that the ionic mobility of the cation and anion are of comparable order so that they can keep the anode and cathode half cells neutral at all times. KNO3 is used because velocities of K+ and NO3− ions are nearly same.

question.text: Resistance of a conductivity cell filled with a solution of an electrolyte of concentration 0.1 M is 100Ω. The conductivity of this solution is 1.29 S m−1. R = 100Ω

$\kappa\ = \ \frac{1}{R}\left( \frac{l}{a} \right)$

$\frac{l}{a}\ $(cell constant) = 1.29 × 100m−1 

Given, R = 520Ω; C = 0.2 M 

µ (molar conductivity) =?

question.text: The electrical resistance of a column of 0.05 M NaOH solution of diameter 1 cm and length 50 cm is 5.55 × 103 Ω. Calculate its resistivity, conductivity and molar conductivity.

solution.text:
The correct option is (A)

For resistivity

We have to find the area.

Area (a) = ${\pi r}^{2} = 3.14 \times \left( \frac{1\ cn}{2} \right)^{2}$

 = 0.785 cm2

 = 0.785 × 10−14m2

I = 50 cm = 0.5m

Now

$R = \frac{\rho I}{a}\ or\ \rho = \frac{Ra}{I} = \frac{5.55 \times 10^{3}\ ohm \times 0.758{cm}^{2}}{50\ cm}$

 = 87.135 ohm cm

$Conductivity\ (k) = \frac{I}{\rho} = \left( \frac{1}{87.135} \right)\ S\ {cm}^{- 1}$

 = 0.01148 S cm−1

Molar conductivity ${\bigwedge_{}^{}}_{m} = \frac{k \times 1000}{M}\ {cm}^{3}\ L^{- 1}$

$= \ \frac{0.01148\ S\ {cm}^{- 1} \times 1000{cm}^{3}L^{- 1}}{0.05mol\ L^{- 1}}$

 = 229.6 S cm2 mol−1

Alternatively

The values of different quantities in SI units (i.e., in terms of “m” instead of “cm”)

$$\rho = \frac{Ra}{1} = \frac{5.55 \times 10^{3}ohm \times 0.785 \times 10^{- 4}m^{2}}{0.5m}$$

 = 87.135  × 10−2 ohm m

$$K = \frac{1}{\rho} = \frac{100}{87.135} = 1.148\ {Sm}^{- 1}$$

and

$\ \bigwedge_{m} = \frac{k}{c} = \frac{1.148\ {Sm}^{- 1}}{50\ mol\ m^{- 3}} = 229.6 \times 10^{- 4}{Sm}^{2}\ {mol}^{- 1}$.

question.text: AgNO3 (aq) was added to an aqueous KCl solution gradually and the conductivity of the solution was measured. The plot of conductance (Λ) versus the volume of AgNO3 is

solution.text:
As AgNO3 is added to solution, KCl will be displaced according to following reaction AgNO3 (aq)+ KCl (aq) → AgCl(s)+ KNO3 (aq)

For every mole of KCl displaced from solution, one mole of KNO3 comes in solution resulting in almost constant conductivity. As the end point is reached, added AgNO3 remain in solution increasing ionic concentration, hence conductivity increases.

question.text: The time required to coat a metal surface of 80 cm2 with 5 × 10-3 cm thick layer of silver with passage of 3 amperes current through a silver nitrate solution is (dsilver = 1.05 g cm-3)

solution.text:

By Faraday’s law, w $= \frac{M}{96500 \times n_{f}}\ \times i \times t$

Where M= Molecular weight, nf = n − factor

In this case,

nf = 1,            M = 108g,      w = 0.42g

$$\therefore 0.42 = \frac{108}{96500 \times 1} \times 3 \times t$$

∴ t = 125 sec.

question.text: For the reaction, N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3, if $\frac{–d\left\lbrack NH_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt}$ = 2 × 10–4 mol L–1 s–1, the value of $\frac{–d\left\lbrack H_{2} \right\rbrack}{dt}$

solution.text:
For reaction, N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3

Rate = $\frac{1}{2}\frac{d\left\lbrack NH_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt} = - \frac{1}{3}\frac{d\left\lbrack H_{2} \right\rbrack}{dt}\ = - \frac{d\left\lbrack N_{2} \right\rbrack}{dt}$

Given, $\frac{d\left\lbrack NH_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt} = 2\ \times 10^{- 4}$ mol L–1 s–1

∴ $- \frac{d\left\lbrack H_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt} = \ \frac{3}{2}\frac{d\left\lbrack {NH}_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt}$ = $\ \frac{3}{2}$ × 2 × 10–4

⇒ $- \frac{d\left\lbrack H_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt}$ = 3 × 10–4 mol L–1 s–1.

question.text: Consider the reaction N2(g) + 3H2(g) → 2NH3(g). The equality relationship between $\frac{d\lbrack NH_{3}\rbrack}{dt}$ and $- \frac{d\lbrack H_{2}\rbrack}{dt}$ is

solution.text:
N2(g) + 3H2(g) → 2NH3(g)

Rate = $\frac{- d\left\lbrack N_{2} \right\rbrack}{dt}$ = $- \frac{d\left\lbrack H_{2} \right\rbrack}{3dt}$ = $\frac{d\left\lbrack {NH}_{3} \right\rbrack}{2dt}$

Hence $\frac{d\left\lbrack {NH}_{3} \right\rbrack}{dt}$ = $- \frac{2}{3}\frac{d\left\lbrack H_{2} \right\rbrack}{dt}$.

question.text:
The experimental data for the reaction, 2A + B2 → 2AB is

The rate equation for the above data is

solution.text:
For the reaction, 2A + B2 = 2AB.

Rate ∝ [A]x [Br2]y. On substituting the given data, we get

From experiment 2, 3.2 × 10–4 ∝ [0.50]x [1.00]y …. (ii)

From experiment 3, 3.2 × 10–4 ∝ [1.00]x [1.00]y …. (iii)

On dividing equation (iii) by (ii), we get,

$1 = \ \left\lbrack \frac{1.00}{0.50} \right\rbrack^{x}$ or, 1 = 2x or 20 = 2x or x = 0

Thus rate equation is: Rate = k[A]0 [B2]1 = k[B2].

question.text: For the reaction H2(g) + I2(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), the rate of reaction is expressed as

question.text: Which increases on increase of temperature?

solution.text: The collision frequency (Z) and rate contant (k) increase on increase of temperature. With the increase in temperature, the average kinetic energy of the molecules increases and this leads to an increase in number of collisions per unit time (Z). question.text: Under the same reaction condition, initial concentration of 1.386 mol dm−3 of a substance become half in 40 s and 20 s through first order and zero order kinetics respectively. Zero order kinetics,$\ k_{0} = \frac{C_{0}}{2t_{1/2}} = \frac{1.386}{2 \times 20}$

question.text:
The basicity of aniline is weaker in comparison to that
of methyl amine due to

d.text: Hyper conjugative effect of Me group in MeNH2
Resonance effect of phenyl group in aniline

Lower molecular weight of methyl amine as compared to that of
aniline
Resonance effect of –NH2 group in MeNH2

solution.text:
lone pair of electrons of N –atom present in Aniline undergoes resonance with the π-electron cloud of benzene ring. As a result, the electron density over N-atom decreases and the tendency of N-atom donate its electron pair to H+ also decreases.

In case of methylamine, this kind of resonance or delocalisation of electrons does not take place. As a result, N-atom of methylamine shows higher tendency to donate its lone pair of electrons to H+ion. For this reason, basicity of aniline is less that of methylamine.

question.text:
Which one of the following does not exhibit the
phenomenon of mutarotation?

solution.text: Sucrose does not show mutarotation. Mutarotation is the phenomenon of change in optical rotation shown by freshly prepared solutions of sugars. However, this property is not exhibited by all sugars. Only those sugars which have a free aldehyde (—CHO) or ketone (>C = O) group are capable of showing mutarotation. Sucrose lacks free aldehyde or ketone group and is therefore incapable of showing mutarotation.

moves to cathode. Alanine does not migrate to any electrode at its
isoelectric point.

question.text:
For the four successive transition elements (Cr, Mn, Fe and Co), the stability of +2 oxidation state will be there in which of the following order?

(At nos. Cr = 24, Mn = 25, Fe = 26, Co = 27)

solution.text:
The order can be explained using the idea of spin correlation. Spin correlation refers to lowering of energy for like (parallel) spins. Spin correlation leading to decrease in repulsion for electrons of like spins than for electrons of different spins is called exchange energy.

Spin correlation and its exchange energy gives an electronic configuration a special stability which is greatest for half-filled electronic configurations.

Mn2+ (d6) gets stabilisation due to half-filled configuration.

In Fe2+ (d6) the placing of one extra electron in a subshell destabilises. Placing of 2 electrons in Co2+ (d7) destabilises it more. Cr2+ (d4) has one vacant subshell. Fe2+ gets more stabilisation compared to Cr2+ through exchange energy. So the order is as follows: Mn >Fe >Cr >Co.

question.text:
Which of the following option is the correct order for
the basic strength of metallic hydroxides

solution.text:
As the size of metal atom increases, M−O bond length increases and the tendency to lose −OH group increases, i.e., basicity increases. 

The order of size of given metallic elements is:
Al3+ < Lu3+ < Ce3+ < Ca2+

Thus, the order of basic strength is:
Al(OH)3​ < Lu(OH)3​ < Ce(OH)3 ​< Ca(OH)2

question.text:
Which one of the following elements shows maximum number
of different oxidation states in its compounds?

solution.text:
'La' forms compounds in which its oxidation no. is +3.

`Eu' and `Gd' exhibit +2 as well as +3 oxidation state and not higher than that, due to stable (f7) configuration whereas 'Am' exhibits the oxidation states +2, +3, +4, +5, +6, etc. due to extremely large size and low ionisation energy.

question.text:
The incorrect statement(s) among(1) – (3) is(are):

  1. W(VI) is more stable than Cr(VI).

  2. In the presence of HCl, permanganate titrations provide satisfactory results.

  3. more lanthanoid oxides can be used as phosphors.

solution.text:
(i) W(VI) is more stable than Cr(VI) due to smaller size of atoms and also due to lanthanide contraction.

(ii) Permanganate titrations is presence of HCl are unsatisfactory as HCl is oxidised to Cl3.

(iii) Lanthanoid oxides are used as phosphors.

question.text:
Reactivity order of halides for dehydrohalogenation
is

d.text: R – F < R – Cl > R – Br > R – I
R – I > R – Br > R – Cl > R – F
R – I > R – Cl > R – Br > R – F
R – F > R – I > R – Br > R – Cl

solution.text:
I > Br > Cl > F → atomic radii.

F, Cl, Br, I belongs to the same group orderly. Atomic radii go on increasing as the nuclear charge increases in preceeding downwards in a group. The decreasing order of bond length C – I > C – Br > C – Cl > C – F. The order of bond dissociation energy R – F > R – Cl > R – Br > R – I.

During dehydrohalogenation C — I bond breaks more easily than C — F bond. So reactivity order of halides R – I > R – Br > R – C1 > R – F.

question.text:
Which of the following Grignard reagent is suitable for
the preparation of 3-methyl-2-butanol?

solution.text:
Methyl magnesium bromide reacts with 2-butanone to form 2-methyl-2-butanol in two steps

The first step involves the nucleophilic attack of the Grignard reagent to the carbonyl group to form an addict. The second step involves acidic hydrolysis of adduct to form alcohol.

question.text:
An ether is more volatile than an alcohol having the
same molecular formula. This is due to

solution.text:
Alcohol has polar H which makes intermolecular H-bonding
possible. Ether is non-polar hence no H-bonding. Lack of H-bonding in
ether makes it more volatile than alcohol.

question.text: If the boiling point of ethanol (molecular weight=46) is 78℃, what is the boiling point of diethyl ether? (molecular weight = 74)

solution.text: Molecular weight of diethyl ether is more than ethanol. Therefore, it should have higher boiling point than ethanol. But it is not so. It is due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Ethyl alcohol has intermolecular hydrogen bonding but diethyl ether has no hydrogen bonding. The compounds shows intermolecular hydrogen bonding has higher m.p. and b.p. than compounds having no hydrogen bonding. Therefore, the boiling point of diethyl ether will be less than ethanol (78℃)

question.text: Which one of the following compounds will not react with CH3MgBr?

solution.text:
Grignard reagent (RMgX) reacts with only those compounds which contains acidic hydrogen or which contains carbonyl group.

Dimethyl ether (CH3OCH3) due to absence of both acidic hydrogen and carbonyl group does not react with Grignard reagent.

question.text: Phenol is soluble in water because

d.text: Of weak hydrogen bonding between phenol and water molecules
Of intermolecular hydrogen bonding between phenol molecules
If has a higher boiling point than that of water

solution.text:
The −OH group in Phenols is involved in the
intermolecular hydrogen bonding with water. Thus, phenol is soluble in
water.

question.text:
Benzoylation of phenol in alkaline medium is known is
known as

solution.text: The process of benzoylation of compounds containing active hydrogen such as phenol, aniline, alcohol etc, with benzoyl chloride in the presence of aqueous NaOH is called Schotten-Baumann reaction.

question.text:
Phenol on treatment with diethyl sulphate in presence of
NaOH gives

solution.text:
Diethyl sulphate in the presence of NaOH acts as alkylating agent, it causes alkylation of phenol to give ethyl phenyl ether which is also called phenetole.

C6H5OH + NaOH → C6H5O−Na+ + H2O

C6H5O−Na+ + (C2H5)2SO4 → C6H5OC2H5ph + C2H5NaSO4

question.text:
Among the following four compounds

(i) Phenol (ii) Methyl phenol

(iii) Meta-nitropheno (iv) para-nitrophenol

The acidity order is

solution.text:
In phenols, the presence of electron releasing groups decrease the acidity, whereas presence of electron withdrawing groups increase the acidity, compared to phenol. Among the meta and para-nitrophenols, the latter is more acidic as the presence of –NO2 group at pars position stabilises the phenoxide ion to a greater extent than when it is present at meta position. Thus, correct order of acidity is :

Para-nitrophenol > meta-nitrophenol

(iv) (iii)

> phenol > methyl phenol

(i) (ii)

question.text:
Which of the following cannot be made by using
Williamson synthesis?

solution.text:
Ditertiary butyl ether will prefer to undergo
elimination leading to alkene rather taking part in the Williamson's
synthesis.

solution.text: Methyl halide form ether with bulky base.

question.text:
Which one of the following compounds is resistant to
nucleophilic attack by hydroxyl ions?

solution.text:
Diethyl ether is a saturated compound, so it is
resistant to nucleophilic attack by a hydroxyl ion (OH<sup>-</sup>).
Other compounds have unsaturation and the unsaturated 'C' atom bears
partial +ve charge, therefore they undergo easy nucleophilic attack by
OH<sup>-</sup> ion.

question.text:
What amount of bromine will be required to convert 2 g
of phenol into 2, 4, 6-tribromo phenol?

solution.text:
Molecular weight of phenol = 12 × 6 + 1 × 6 + 16 = 94

Molecular weight. Of Br2 = 3 × 160 = 480

∵ 94 g of phenol requires=480g of Br2

∴ 2 g phenol requires = $\frac{480}{94} \times 2 = 10.22$ g

question.text: Arrange the following compounds in increasing order of C – OH bond length; methanol, phenol, p-ethoxyphenol

solution.text:
Resonance is a deciding factor to determine the order of bond length in given compounds.

Phenol exhibits least C – OH bond length due to resonance, whereas methanol will show

maximum bend length due to lack of resonance and p-ethoxyphenol will have some

intermediate value of bond length.
